topic: Deep dive: _datetime standard library module in Python 3.12+
prompt: Write a Python 3.12+ focused, accurate explainer for: Deep dive: _datetime standard library module in Python 3.12+

response_parsed.title: Deep Dive: _datetime Standard Library Module in Python 3.12+
response_parsed.summary: This explainer provides a comprehensive overview of the enhancements and new features introduced in the _datetime standard library module for Python 3.12+.
key_points: Improved performance with new algorithms for date and time arithmetic operations.
Support for additional time zones, including historical time zones.
Enhanced support for Daylight Saving Time rules and leap seconds.
New functionality to handle Julian dates and Greek orthodox Easter calculations.

code_examples.code:
from datetime import datetime

# New date in a specific time zone
date = datetime(2023, 5, 10, tzinfo=pytz.UTC)
print(date)

from datetime import timedelta

# Adding a specific duration to a date
duration = timedelta(days=5, hours=2, minutes=30)
date += duration
print(date)

version_notes: Many of the improvements and new features are not available in earlier versions of Python.
It is recommended to use the most recent version of Python for optimal results.
caveats: The _datetime module can be complex to master, but understanding its capabilities will greatly enhance your ability to work with dates and times in Python.
Be sure to install the pytz library if you need to work with time zones.
